ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about the techniques of making silverware and the manufacturing of silverware during different time periods and historical context.
How to identify, categorize, and interpret silver from the gallerys collections! Object handling and close looking
great course on american silver over the centuries
This is a wonderful course. I learned the rich history of American Silver, how to closely analyze objects both ornate and mundane, and how to conduct thorough art history research.
I learned how to research an object and how to recognize silver objects from different periods based on style, workmanship, and other standout elements.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The class is really fun to take and we have many opportunities to touch silver objects and look at them up-close.
hands on learning with silver objects from the yuag!
The class is great -- each seminar was incredibly engaging, the readings were interesting, the assignments were fair and well spaced out. I have no real notes.

This course is very hands-on which is great, but the 2 hour classes ultimately end up being a lecture style while each object is passed from student to student. I'm not sure how else it would be taught but be prepared for more of a lecture format than a section-style format. Class is pretty quiet, also.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes!!!! John is amazing and super funny and friendly. The readings are great and every class is a joy to attend. My favorite class this semester by far!

American Silver was FANTASTIC! Professor Gordon is such a fun and engaging lecturer and getting to handle 10+ objects every class was so unique and interesting. This class seriously transformed the way I look at silver and American art and was very very accessible to students from non art history backgrounds. Class discussions were engaging and assignments were well thought out and fun to do. Cannot recommend this course enough.
yes! seeing the objects you are learning about in person is insanely cool
Yes! Professor Gordon is awesome and the class really takes advantage of the resources of the YUAG.

I would recommend this course whether you do or don't have any art history knowledge. I've taken a lot of art history courses at Yale and one of the great things about this is being able to handle objects directly each week. You adopt 1 object and get to spend a lot of time researching it, and the assignments are a great first brush with art history since you're writing museum labels, research papers, and acquisition proposals...as art history classes go, this is actually one of the more practical ones. There wasn't much feedback on written assignments but I think where you stand in the course is relatively clear, and the class overall was not too much work - well spread out over the semester. Also JSG knows everything about silver and this is a wonderful opportunity to learn from a curator!
